  4. Harassment and intimidation;
  5. Threats to families and staff;
  6. Domestic and foreign threat actors;

  7. Trends and emerging threats;

  8. Data Sources:

  9. U.S. Capitol Police incident reports;
  10. FBI threat assessments;
  11. Secret Service protective intelligence;
  12. Intelligence community reporting;
  13. Social media monitoring;

  14. Member and staff surveys;

  15. Threat Classification:

  16. Commission classifies threats by:
    • Severity (credible vs. aspirational);
    • Target (member, staff, family, office);
    • Type (physical, cyber, harassment);
    • Actor (domestic extremist, foreign, individual);

  17. Classification informs resource allocation;

  18. Annual Threat Report:

  19. Classified report to appropriate congressional committees;
  20. Unclassified summary for public release;
  21. Trends and recommendations;
  22. Budget implications.

(2) Intelligence Community Coordination

Commission coordinates with intelligence and law enforcement:

  1. U.S. Capitol Police:
  2. Primary protective agency for Congress;
  3. Commission receives threat briefings;

  4. Commission coordinates on security requirements;

  5. Federal Bureau of Investigation:

  6. Domestic terrorism and threat assessment;
  7. Cybersecurity threat intelligence;

  8. Investigations of threats against members;

  9. Secret Service:

  10. Protective intelligence;
  11. Best practices from Presidential and VIP protection;

  12. Technical security expertise;

  13. Intelligence Community:

  14. Foreign threat intelligence;
  15. Cyber threat intelligence from NSA, DHS;

  16. Classified briefings for Commission;

  17. Department of Homeland Security:

  18. Critical infrastructure protection;
  19. Cybersecurity support;
  20. Coordination on district office security.

(3) Individual Threat Level Determinations

Commission assesses individual member threat levels:

  1. Threat Factors:
  2. Committee assignments (some committees attract more threats);
  3. High-profile legislative activity;
  4. Media visibility and controversial positions;
  5. Demographics (threats may target members based on race, religion, gender);
  6. Geographic location and district characteristics;

  7. Past incidents and threats;

  8. Threat Levels:

  9. Baseline: All members face some threat requiring basic security;
  10. Elevated: Members facing increased threats requiring enhanced security;

  11. High: Members under credible, specific threats requiring comprehensive security;

  12. Confidential Assessments:

  13. Individual threat assessments remain confidential;
  14. Shared only with member, Capitol Police, and relevant protective agencies;

  15. Commission uses threat levels to allocate security funding without disclosing individual assessments;

  16. Quarterly Reassessment:

  17. Threat levels reassessed quarterly;
  18. Adjustments made as threat environment changes;
  19. Ensures security resources match current threats.

(4) Emerging Threat Identification

Commission monitors for new threat types:

  1. Technology-Enabled Threats:
  2. Deepfakes targeting members;
  3. Doxing of members, staff, and families;
  4. Swatting and false emergency calls;

  5. Social media harassment campaigns;

  6. Organized Campaigns:

  7. Coordinated harassment by extremist groups;
  8. Foreign influence operations;

  9. Domestic terrorism targeting government;

  10. Novel Attack Methods:

  11. Drone threats;
  12. Biological and chemical threats;

  13. Vehicle ramming attacks;

  14. Insider Threats:

  15. Staff radicalization;
  16. Unauthorized information disclosure;
  17. Workplace violence.

(5) Risk Mitigation Strategies

Commission develops comprehensive risk mitigation:

  1. Physical Security:
  2. Hardening facilities;
  3. Access control and surveillance;

  4. Protective personnel;

  5. Cybersecurity:

  6. Protecting communications and data;
  7. Monitoring for intrusions;

  8. Incident response;

  9. Personal Security:

  10. Protective details for high-risk members;
  11. Travel security;

  12. Residential security;

  13. Training and Awareness:

  14. Security awareness training for members and staff;
  15. Recognizing and reporting threats;
  16. Emergency response procedures.

(6) Security Clearance Coordination

Commission coordinates security clearances:

  1. Clearance Requirements:
  2. Members receive appropriate clearances for committee work;

  3. Senior staff receive clearances as needed;

  4. Clearance Processing:

  5. Commission coordinates with FBI and intelligence community;

  6. Expedited processing for newly elected members;

  7. Classified Information Handling:

  8. Secure facilities for classified briefings;
  9. Protocols for handling classified information;
  10. Training on classified information security.

docs.title: (b) Physical Security Funding
docs.text:
Commission establishes Security Class funding separate from MRA:

(1) Separate Security Classification Funding

Security funding independent of MRA prevents impossible trade-offs:

  1. Rationale:
  2. Members should not choose between hiring staff and ensuring safety;
  3. Security is non-negotiable requirement, not optional expense;
  4. Security costs vary dramatically based on threat level, not office size or district characteristics;

  5. Funding security through MRA creates perverse incentives and inadequate security;

  6. Security Budget Structure:

  7. Separate "Security Class" appropriation;
  8. Allocated based on threat assessment, not political considerations;
  9. Managed by Capitol Police and Commission;

  10. Members receive security resources based on need, not budget negotiations;

  11. Transparency and Oversight:

  12. Aggregate security funding disclosed;
  13. Individual member allocations remain confidential to protect security;

  14. GAO audits security spending for efficiency and effectiveness;

  15. Flexibility:

  16. Security funding adjusts rapidly as threats evolve;
  17. No waiting for budget cycles when member under immediate threat.

(2) District Office Security

Commission funds comprehensive district office security:

  1. Bulletproof Glass and Reinforced Structures:
  2. Windows replaced with bullet-resistant glazing;
  3. Reinforced doors and frames;
  4. Safe rooms or reinforced areas for emergency shelter;

  5. Funding based on threat level and office configuration;

  6. Access Control Systems:

  7. Controlled entry with visitor screening;
  8. Badge access for staff;
  9. Visitor management systems;
  10. Panic buttons and duress alarms;

  11. Integration with law enforcement;

  12. Surveillance and Monitoring:

  13. Security cameras covering all entry points and public areas;
  14. Recording and monitoring systems;
  15. Integration with Capitol Police monitoring center;

  16. Privacy protections for staff and constituents;

  17. Panic Buttons and Emergency Systems:

  18. Panic buttons at reception and throughout office;
  19. Direct connection to law enforcement;
  20. Emergency evacuation plans and procedures;

  21. Regular drills and training;

  22. Security Personnel:

  23. For high-threat offices, security officers on-site;
  24. Trained in protective operations and emergency response;
  25. Coordination with local law enforcement;
  26. Funding through Security Class budget, not MRA.

(3) DC Office Security Enhancements

Commission coordinates Capitol complex and DC office security:

  1. Capitol Complex Security:
  2. U.S. Capitol Police primary responsibility;
  3. Commission coordinates on requirements and funding;

  4. Enhanced security for high-risk members;

  5. DC Office Space:

  6. Security features in office build-outs;
  7. Access control and surveillance;

  8. Integration with Capitol Police systems;

  9. Parking and Commuting:

  10. Secure parking for members;
  11. Commute security for high-risk members;
  12. Coordination with Secret Service and Capitol Police.

(4) Residential Security for High-Risk Members

Commission funds home security when necessary:

  1. Home Security Systems:
  2. Professionally installed and monitored systems;
  3. Cameras, alarms, and access control;
  4. 24/7 monitoring with law enforcement response;

  5. Privacy-respecting implementation;

  6. Monitoring Services:

  7. Central station monitoring;
  8. Direct connection to local police;

  9. Mobile alert systems;

  10. Physical Upgrades:

  11. Reinforced doors and windows where appropriate;
  12. Landscape security (lighting, sightlines);

  13. Safe rooms in highest-risk cases;

  14. Security Details:

  15. For members under acute, credible threats, protective details;
  16. Coordination with Capitol Police and Secret Service;

  17. Funding adequate for 24/7 protection when necessary;

  18. Family Protection:

  19. Security extends to member families when threatened;
  20. Coordination with schools and workplaces;
  21. Privacy and normalcy balanced with safety.

docs.title: (c) Cybersecurity Standards
docs.text:
Commission establishes mandatory cybersecurity requirements:

(1) Personal Device Security Requirements

All member and staff devices secured to federal standards:

  1. Mobile Device Management:
  2. All smartphones and tablets enrolled in MDM;
  3. Remote wipe capability if device lost/stolen;
  4. Enforced security policies (encryption, passwords);

  5. Application whitelisting;

  6. Encryption:

  7. Device encryption mandatory;
  8. Communications encryption (email, messaging);

  9. Data at rest and in transit encrypted;

  10. Security Software:

  11. Antivirus and anti-malware on all devices;
  12. Regular updates and scans;

  13. Threat detection and response;

  14. Secure Configuration:

  15. Devices configured per federal security baselines;
  16. Unnecessary services disabled;
  17. Security patches applied promptly.

(2) Communications Encryption

All congressional communications protected:

  1. Email Encryption:
  2. Email encrypted in transit and at rest;
  3. End-to-end encryption for sensitive communications;

  4. Digital signatures for authentication;

  5. Messaging Encryption:

  6. Secure messaging apps for sensitive discussions;
  7. End-to-end encryption mandatory;

  8. Ephemeral messaging for highly sensitive matters;

  9. Voice and Video:

  10. Secure voice calling;
  11. Encrypted video conferencing;

  12. Protection against interception;

  13. Cloud Storage:

  14. Congressional documents stored in secure cloud;
  15. Encryption and access controls;
  16. Audit logging;
  17. Compliance with federal security requirements.

(3) Email and Data Protection

Comprehensive email and data security:

  1. Email Security:
  2. Spam and phishing filtering;
  3. Malicious attachment scanning;
  4. Link analysis and URL rewriting;

  5. Employee training on phishing recognition;

  6. Data Loss Prevention:

  7. Systems preventing unauthorized data disclosure;
  8. Classification and handling rules;
  9. Monitoring for suspicious data transfers;

  10. Incident response procedures;

  11. Backup and Recovery:

  12. Regular backups of all systems;
  13. Secure backup storage;
  14. Tested recovery procedures;

  15. Ransomware protection;

  16. Access Controls:

  17. Multi-factor authentication required;
  18. Role-based access control;
  19. Least privilege principle;
  20. Regular access reviews.

(4) Social Media Security Protocols

Protection for member and office social media:

  1. Account Security:
  2. Strong passwords and multi-factor authentication;
  3. Recovery procedures;

  4. Regular security audits;

  5. Content Security:

  6. Review procedures for posts;
  7. Protection against impersonation;

  8. Crisis response procedures for compromises;

  9. Privacy Protection:

  10. Guidelines on personal information sharing;
  11. Protection of location data;

  12. Family privacy considerations;

  13. Threat Monitoring:

  14. Monitoring for threats in social media;
  15. Coordination with law enforcement;
  16. Documenting threats for protective intelligence.

(5) Staff Cybersecurity Training

Comprehensive training program:

  1. Initial Training:
  2. All new staff complete cybersecurity training within first week;
  3. Covers basics (passwords, phishing, device security);

  4. Office-specific security procedures;

  5. Annual Refresher:

  6. Annual cybersecurity training for all staff;
  7. Updates on emerging threats;

  8. Reinforcement of best practices;

  9. Role-Specific Training:

  10. Enhanced training for staff with sensitive data access;
  11. Technical training for IT staff;

  12. Security clearance training;

  13. Simulated Attacks:

  14. Periodic phishing simulations;
  15. Training based on results;
  16. Building security awareness culture.

(6) Incident Response Procedures

Procedures for handling security incidents:

  1. Incident Detection:
  2. Monitoring systems detect anomalies;
  3. Staff report suspicious activity;

  4. Automated alerts for security events;

  5. Response Procedures:

  6. Defined response procedures by incident type;
  7. Roles and responsibilities;
  8. Escalation procedures;

  9. Communication protocols;

  10. Investigation:

  11. Forensic analysis of incidents;
  12. Determining scope and impact;

  13. Identifying attackers where possible;

  14. Remediation:

  15. Containing and eliminating threats;
  16. Restoring systems and data;

  17. Preventing recurrence;

  18. Reporting:

  19. Incidents reported to Capitol Police, FBI, DHS as appropriate;
  20. Internal reporting to Commission;
  21. Public disclosure when necessary.

(7) Threat Monitoring and Detection

Proactive threat monitoring:

  1. Network Monitoring:
  2. Continuous monitoring of congressional networks;
  3. Intrusion detection systems;
  4. Anomaly detection;

  5. Threat intelligence integration;

  6. Endpoint Monitoring:

  7. Monitoring member and staff devices;
  8. Malware detection;

  9. Suspicious activity alerts;

  10. Threat Intelligence:

  11. Intelligence feeds on threats targeting government;
  12. Coordination with intelligence community;

  13. Information sharing with other branches;

  14. Security Operations Center:

  15. Centralized security monitoring for Congress;
  16. 24/7 operations;
  17. Incident response coordination;
  18. Integration with Capitol Police.

docs.title: (d) Travel Security

END OF TITLE IV PART A

This completes Sections 401-403 of Title IV: Scope of Authority.
